How will Belgians vote at the 2024 elections?
Monday 3 April 2023
By  Ugo Realfonzo

A Belgian flag pictured at the Royal Palace in Brussels. Credit: Hatim Kaghat / Belga
The latest poll conducted, by a consortium of Belgian media organisations, Het Laatste Nieuws, Le Soir, RTL TVi and VTM, has outlined the political preferences of Belgian voters ahead of the 2024 Federal Elections.
The results confirmed previous ideas of Belgian politics: a predominantly left-leaning Wallonia, a centre-left leaning in Brussels and a strong right-wing in Flanders, geared towards independence.
Regionally, the francophone liberal party MR is leading in Brussels, closely courted by the Belgian Workers’ Party (PTB). In Flanders, Flemish nationalists Vlaams Belang and N-VA (far-right and right-wing respectively) are the two leading parties, while in Wallonia, Paul Magnette’s socialists break away from George Louis Bouchez’s MR.
In terms of popularity, three liberal politicians come out on top: Alexander De Croo, Sophie Wilmès, and Hadja Lahbib.
Belgium
Among the political families at the Belgian level, the francophone Socialist Party (PS) and Vouruit in Flanders – both part of the S&D group in the European Parliament – have the largest seat projection at the national level with 32.
Tied at 24 seats are Vlaams Belang – an indication of its dominance in Flanders – and the liberal political family, MR and Open VLD (Renew in the European Parliament), with the latter being up two.
N-VA is in fourth with 20 seats, but like Vlaams Belang, only Flemish people are able to vote for them, meaning they are propelled into parliament thanks to huge support in the Flemish region. The Belgian worker party (PTB-PDVA) is stable at 18 seats. The Belgian Green Parties (Ecolo and Groen) have lost one seat, down to 15.
However, with 81 seats, the current Federal Government (PS, MR, Ecolo, Groen, CD&V, Open VLD, Vooruit) retains the majority in the Federal Parliament, according to projections. The result of 81 seats is better (by one) than the previous survey carried out last December, but still well below the 87 seats obtained in the May 2019 parliamentary elections.
Brussels
Francophone liberals MR lead across the Brussels-Capital Region with 20%, closely tailed by a significant rise of the Belgian Workers Party (PTB)–  who are up 3% to 19%, and are ahead of the Socialist Party (PS) and francophone greens, Ecolo.
MR, which polled 19.8% of voting intentions, is first in the ranking but is down 0.5% from the survey of last December, but still 2.3% better than in the 2019 elections.
Behind them, the PTB is making up the ground at a substantial pace, jumping from 12.3% of the vote in the 2019 elections to 19.4% of voting intentions today, and is only 0.4% behind leaders MR.
In third place, the Socialist Party (PS) continues to drop heavily. In the latest poll, PS counted 16.8% of voting intentions, compared to 20% of the vote in 2019, and 21.6% of voting intentions in the December 2022 poll.
Fourth with 15.7%, the francophone greens, Ecolo, slightly improved their result from the previous poll in December, where it received 13%, but is doing worse than in the 2019 elections, where it won 21.6% of the vote.
Stable, centrists Défi polled 10.2% of voting intentions, while conservatives Les Engagés are down to 5.1% of voting intentions, compared to 5.8% of the vote in 2019.
Wallonia
In the southern region of the country, the gap is widening between socialists and liberals. The Socialist Party (PS) continues to go from strength to strength under leader Paul Magnette, who is also the Mayor of Charleroi.
In first, PS polled a comfortable 26%, while the gap with second-placed MR (19%) led by George Louis Bouchez, has widened by 7% – the largest between the two main political formations in Wallonia since the beginning of the legislature. The Belgian Workers Party (PTB) is in third with 18%, and the Greens (Ecolo) with 13%.
There is also less than one percentage point difference between MR and PTB, the third largest party in terms of voting intentions. In the past, PTB has already achieved better results in the survey, but like Ecolo, they are stable. The former at 17.6% this time and the latter at 12.8%, scores that have changed little since December 2022.
A significant breakthrough is finally to be found on the side of the Engagés, which finally regains some colour with 11.1% of voting intentions.
Flanders
In Flanders, aside from the seemingly unsurmountable rise of nationalist right-wing independentism, the party of Belgian Prime Minister Alexander De Croo has sunk to its lowest results ever recorded for the party in Flanders: 9%.
Far-right party Vlaams Belang is still leading the polls in the Flemish region, with 25% expressing a preference for the separatists and nationalists.
In second place, another Flemish independence party, N-VA remains stable at 22% – with leader and Antwerp Mayor Bart De Wever’s recent anti-woke push seemingly not having made as much of a splash as was maybe hoped.

Philippe Mongrain

April 22nd, 2024

Belgium: the 2024 federal elections – deadlock ahead?

0 comments
          | 9 shares

Estimated reading time: 6 minutes

Belgium will hold simultaneous federal, regional and European elections on 9 June. Philippe Mongrain and Karolin Soontjens preview the vote, writing that while it is difficult to predict the outcome, the tide seems to have turned in favour of more radical parties.



This article is part of a series on the 2024 European Parliament elections. The EUROPP blog will also be co-hosting a panel discussion on the elections at LSE on 6 June.

On 9 June, Belgians will head to the polls for the first time in five years, making this the longest period without any parliamentary elections since the Second World War. Voters will cast their ballots for members of the regional, federal and European parliaments.

During the last federal elections in 2019, we witnessed a weakening of the ruling parties (N-VA, MR, Open Vld, CD&V) and, more generally, of traditional party families. Liberals (Open Vld, MR), Social Democrats (SP.A/Vooruit, PS) and Christian Democrats (CD&V, cdH/LE) gathered less than 50 percent of the vote, a first since the Second Word War (see Figure 1).

The decline of these party factions primarily benefited more radical alternatives on both sides of the ideological spectrum. Vlaams Belang (VB), a Flemish nationalist and right-wing populist party that advocates for the independence of Flanders and stricter immigration policies, managed to significantly increase its presence in parliament, gaining 18 seats in 2019 compared to just three in 2014.

On the far left, the communist Workers’ Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) gained 12 seats, up from only two in 2014. It appears that Vlaams Belang was able to attract mostly previous N-VA supporters – despite the latter’s efforts to prevent voters from shifting to the far right by adopting a tougher stance on immigration. Meanwhile, the PVDA-PTB mostly appealed to former SP.A (now Vooruit) and Groen supporters in Flanders, as well as Socialist (PS) voters in Wallonia and Brussels.

Figure 1: Results of the 2014 and 2019 Belgian federal elections



Note: Data from IBZ – SPF Intérieur. Semi-transparent bars show 2014 results. Solid bars show 2019 results. DéFI was formerly known as FDF, Les Engagés (LE) as cdH, and Vooruit as sp.a.

The outcome of the 2019 federal elections further exacerbated the divergence between an already more right-leaning Flanders and more left-leaning Wallonia. The election results largely mirrored the policy priorities in each region, with immigration being higher on the public agenda in Flanders, while socioeconomic issues were the top issues among Walloon voters. Moreover, the growth of extreme parties and the refusal of mainstream parties to govern with the far right (as part of the “cordon sanitaire”) have significantly complicated the government formation process.

Following the collapse of the Michel government in December 2018 due to the N-VA’s opposition to the Global Compact for Migration, the country went through 652 days of temporary arrangements and caretaker governments. Since October 2020, Belgium has been governed by a coalition of seven parties (the so-called “Vivaldi” coalition) – excluding the two largest parties in Flanders, the N-VA and VB – with Alexander De Croo, leading figure of the Open Vld, as prime minister.

Most polls conducted after the 2019 elections have shown Vlaams Belang ahead of the N-VA by a few points in terms of vote intentions (see Figure 2). This marks an important shift from the 2014–2019 election cycle during which the N-VA was by far the largest party. Recent polls suggest that Vlaams Belang would secure at least a quarter of the votes in Flanders, translating to approximately 25 seats in the federal Chamber of Representatives if elections were held today, making it the largest party in parliament.

Figure 2: Voting intention and seat projections for the Belgian federal elections (May 2014 – March 2024)



Note: Data from Wikipedia. Semi-transparent markers represent individual polls. Trend lines are local regressions (losses). Diamond-framed markers show the actual vote share/number of seats won by each party on election day.

The three Flemish centre-right formations (CD&V, N-VA and Open Vld) as well as the Greens are experiencing a (large) decline in support compared to the previous elections. This expected loss of support is greatest for the prime minister’s party (Open Vld), for which the polls predict an historically low result of around eight percent.

For a long time, the polls were much more positive for the centre-left party Vooruit, which was polling at over 16 percent last year. Recently, though, the polls report much lower support, following controversies surrounding its former chairman, Conner Rousseau, who resigned over racist remarks in November 2023. Vooruit now finds itself almost neck-and-neck with the CD&V at approximately 11 percent.

However, Rousseau has recently announced his comeback and will be actively involved in the campaign, hoping to reverse the recent negative trend in the polls. While the progression of the Flemish socialists has been halted, the PVDA appears to be gaining new supporters in Flanders: around 10 percent of Flemish voters say they intend to vote for the PVDA, twice its score in the previous federal election. In fact, communists are making headway in all three regions, with support for the PVDA-PTB hovering around 16-18 percent in Wallonia and Brussels.

The Socialist Party (PS) continues to lead vote intention polls in Wallonia, closely followed by the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR), which currently holds the top position in Brussels. The centrist Les Engagés (LE) is also improving its score among voters in both Wallonia and Brussels, while Ecolo appears to be losing support in both regions.

Government formation

These polls hint at a complicated government formation process, mainly because the rise of extreme parties (PVDA-PTB and Vlaams Belang) makes it challenging to form governments with a limited number of mainstream parties. All parties explicitly refute the possibility of forming a government with Vlaams Belang – except for some N-VA politicians who have declared their willingness to break the cordon sanitaire. In addition, most parties have stated they would refuse any coalition agreement with the PVDA-PTB.

In most polls, the current federal Vivaldi coalition maintains a majority, albeit only in Brussels and Wallonia. Hence, Vivaldi II might be possible, but the dynamics between the current Vivaldi parties would shift substantially, with Open Vld taking a much weaker position and vice versa for the socialist parties.

Another coalition that sporadically gains majority support in the polls is the so-called “Burgundian coalition” with the N-VA, liberals (MR and Open Vld) and socialists (PS and Vooruit), perhaps with the Christian Democrats too. However, the enthusiasm for such a large coalition seems low.

An alternative possibility is forming a federal minority cabinet. The N-VA for instance has advocated for such a minority government with the socialists – possibly securing around 55-60 seats. However, it is hard to see why socialists, especially the PS in Wallonia which is losing voters to the PTB, would be in favour of such a set-up. The PS would rather lean towards a left-wing government including socialists, greens, communists and Christian Democrats. This kind of federal coalition would have a substantial majority in Brussels and Wallonia, but not in Flanders. Plus, it is highly uncertain whether the Christian Democrats are willing to govern with the communists in the first place.

With over a month remaining before Belgians head to the polls, one can only be cautious about making electoral forecasts. Nonetheless, it seems relatively safe to say that, over the past years, the tide seems to have turned in favour of more radical parties, mirroring recent trends in other European countries and leaving traditional mainstream parties in decline. This is particularly true for Vlaams Belang, which can look at the recent success of the Dutch far-right PVV party in 2023 as a rather good omen.

## Opinion polls

Opinion polling in the lead-up to the 2024 Belgian federal election revealed several significant trends, continuing patterns from the 2019 elections and highlighting the complexities of Belgium's political landscape. A key observation was the continued weakening of traditional mainstream parties and the corresponding rise in support for parties on the far-right and far-left of the political spectrum <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. Polling data was regularly published by firms such as Ipsos, Kantar, iVox, and De Stemming, and aggregated by platforms like PolitPro and Politico <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024, https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/belgium/</citation>.

**Overall National Trends:**
Polls consistently showed a political landscape deeply divided along regional and ideological lines. The divergence between a more right-leaning Flanders and a more left-leaning Wallonia remained a defining characteristic <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The growth of the far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) and the far-left Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) complicated predictions for government formation, with most established parties hesitant to form coalitions with these extremes <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Flanders:**
In Flanders, the far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) consistently polled as one of the largest, if not the largest, party. An Ipsos poll from early June 2024, for instance, placed VB at 25.8% and the Flemish nationalist New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) at 21% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. The Christian Democratic and Flemish (CD&V) party was polling around 12.3% in the same poll. The socialist party Vooruit, after a period of growth, stabilized around 15.6% following controversies surrounding its former chairman <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024, https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. Conversely, the Open Flemish Liberals and Democrats (Open Vld), the party of then Prime Minister Alexander De Croo, faced historically low polling numbers, around 7% in early June 2024 <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. The Flemish Greens (Groen) were polling around 6.1%, while the Workers' Party (PVDA) showed notable gains, reaching around 10.2% in Flanders <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024, https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
In Wallonia, the Socialist Party (PS) generally led the polls, though the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) often ran a close second or even matched them. An Ipsos poll from late May 2024, for example, showed both PS and MR at 22.6% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. The Workers' Party (PTB) also demonstrated strong support, polling around 14.5% in the same poll, and other polls showed them even higher at times <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024, https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The centrist party Les Engagés (formerly cdH) showed signs of recovery, polling at 18.1% in late May 2024, while the green party Ecolo polled around 8.8% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**Brussels:**
The political situation in the Brussels-Capital Region was also competitive. The Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was frequently reported as the leading party. Final opinion polls conducted in late May 2024 (May 29-31) indicated MR maintaining a lead with 22.9% of voting intentions, followed by PTB at 19.8% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. This was consistent with earlier polls in 2023 and 2024 which also showed MR in a strong position, with PTB, PS, and Ecolo as other major contenders <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections, https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. For example, an April 2023 poll had shown MR at 20%, PTB at 19%, PS at 16.8%, and Ecolo at 15.7% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections</citation>.

**Final Polls and Implications:**
The final polls leading up to the June 9 election largely reinforced these established trends. The predicted rise of parties at the extremes of the political spectrum, particularly Vlaams Belang in Flanders and PTB-PVDA across regions, alongside the varied performance of traditional parties, pointed towards a complex process of government formation at the federal level, potentially leading to prolonged negotiations <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/, https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>.

## Opinion polls

Opinion polls in the lead-up to the 2024 Belgian federal election painted a complex and evolving political landscape, highlighting regional divergences and shifts in party support. Several polling organizations, including Ipsos, Kantar, and iVox, conducted surveys, with results often aggregated and analyzed by media outlets and platforms like PolitPro and POLITICO.

**Overall National Trends**

Polls consistently indicated a challenging environment for some traditional mainstream parties, with notable gains for parties on the far-right and far-left of the political spectrum <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The Flemish nationalist and far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) was frequently polled as potentially the largest party in Flanders and, consequently, a major force at the federal level. The Workers' Party of Belgium (PTB/PVDA) also showed continued growth across all regions. Projections based on polls leading up to March 2024 suggested Vlaams Belang could secure around 25 seats in the federal Chamber of Representatives <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

The final opinion polls conducted between May 29-31, 2024, just before the election, suggested that in federal voting intentions, the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was holding a lead at 22.9%, closely followed by the PTB at 19.8%. This represented a significant increase for PTB compared to their 2019 results <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>.

**Regional Breakdowns**

*   **Flanders:** In the northern region of Flanders, polls consistently showed a battle for dominance between the far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) and the Flemish nationalist New Flemish Alliance (N-VA).
    *   An Ipsos poll released around June 4, 2024, placed VB at 25.8%, N-VA at 21%, the socialist Vooruit at 15.6%, the Christian Democrats (CD&V) at 12.3%, the Workers' Party (PVDA) at 10.2%, the liberal Open Vld (party of the then Prime Minister) at 7%, and the Greens (Groen) at 6.1% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
    *   Earlier polls in May 2024 from Ipsos and iVox showed similar trends, with VB generally polling between 25-27% and N-VA around 20-22% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Open Vld consistently polled at historically low levels <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. Vooruit saw a period of growth but faced challenges later, while PVDA showed an upward trend <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

*   **Wallonia:** In the southern French-speaking region of Wallonia, the Socialist Party (PS) and the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) were the main competitors.
    *   An Ipsos poll from May 20, 2024, indicated a tight race, with both PS and MR at 22.6%. They were followed by the centrist Les Engagés (LE) at 18.1%, and the Workers' Party (PTB) at 14.5% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. The Greens (Ecolo) were polling lower than in previous elections. The aforementioned final federal poll snippet also highlighted MR's strength and PTB's significant rise in French-speaking Belgium <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>.

*   **Brussels:** The Brussels-Capital Region, officially bilingual, presented a multi-polar political landscape.

*   Open Vld (OVLD), the Flemish liberal party of the Prime Minister, polled at 7%, a significant drop <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Groen (Flemish Greens) were at 6.1% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
Wallonia, the French-speaking southern region, generally leaned more to the left.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) traditionally led in Wallonia. An Ipsos poll from May 20, 2024, showed PS at 22.6%, neck-and-neck with MR <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. An earlier Kantar poll from April 18, 2024, had PS leading more clearly at 25.4% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was the second major force, polling at 22.6% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB, the francophone wing of PVDA) also showed strong support, polling at 14.5% (Ipsos, May 20) to 16% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Les Engagés (LE, formerly cdH, centrist) showed improvement, polling at 18.1% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Ecolo (Francophone Greens) were polling around 8.8% (Ipsos, May 20) to 12.7% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>, indicating a loss of support compared to previous elections <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Brussels:**
The Brussels-Capital Region, officially bilingual but largely French-speaking, presented a distinct political dynamic.
*   Final opinion polls conducted between May 29-31, 2024, indicated that for federal voting intentions, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) held a "healthy lead" at 22.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. This was also reflected in earlier 2024 polls, such as an Ipsos poll from March 18, 2024, which placed MR at 21.8% in Brussels <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB-PVDA) was reported as "tailing" MR in the final May polls at 19.8%, representing a significant increase from their 2019 federal election result <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. The March 18 Ipsos poll showed PVDA at 17.5% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) polled at 15.4% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Some later polls from PolitPro showed varying figures, with one May 20 Ipsos poll indicating Open VLD surprisingly high, which seemed to be an outlier compared to other data and analyses <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Ecolo, the francophone Greens, polled at 14.7% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**National Outlook and Seat Projections**
While specific nationwide seat projections varied between pollsters, the LSE Europp blog in April 2024 noted that Vlaams Belang's projected support in Flanders could translate to approximately 25 seats in the 150-seat federal Chamber of Representatives, potentially making it the largest single party in parliament <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. An April 2023 poll analysis by The Brussels Times suggested that the then-current seven-party "Vivaldi" federal government coalition (PS, MR, Ecolo, Groen, CD&V, Open VLD, Vooruit) was projected to retain a slim majority of 81 seats, down from 87 in 2019 <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections</citation>. However, the declining fortunes of parties like Open Vld suggested that even if a similar coalition were mathematically possible, the internal dynamics would shift significantly <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

The rise of extremist parties (PVDA-PTB and Vlaams Belang), with whom most mainstream parties refused to govern (the "cordon sanitaire" against Vlaams Belang being a key factor), pointed towards another potentially lengthy and complicated government formation process <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

## Background

The 2024 Belgian federal election, held on June 9, 2024, was a pivotal moment in the nation's political landscape. These elections were conducted concurrently with regional parliamentary elections and the European Parliament elections, creating a "super Sunday" of voting that shaped governance at multiple levels <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008707/making-sense-of-the-belgian-elections</citation>.

Belgium operates as a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy. In this system, the King serves as a symbolic head of state, while the substantive political power rests with the Prime Minister and the federal government, which is accountable to a bicameral federal parliament <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation>. The country's political system is renowned for its complexity, largely due to its organization around representing the main linguistic and cultural communities: the Dutch-speaking Flemish, the French-speaking Walloons, and a smaller German-speaking community. Since approximately 1970, major national political parties have bifurcated along linguistic lines, creating distinct Flemish and Francophone parties <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation> <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. This intricate structure is the result of six state reforms undertaken between 1970 and 2014, which progressively transformed Belgium into a federal state composed of communities and regions, often reflecting and attempting to manage ongoing political tensions and regional divergences <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federale_staat</citation> <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. Consequently, forming coalition governments is a standard but often protracted process; for instance, the "Vivaldi" coalition government led by Prime Minister Alexander De Croo, which preceded the 2024 election, took 494 days to form following the May 2019 federal election <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation> <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.

The 2024 federal election was notable for being the first such vote since the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite Belgium having a system of compulsory voting (introduced in 1893), it recorded one of the lowest voter turnouts since the system's inception <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. 前面已写的内容：#### French-speaking constituencies

The 2024 Belgian federal election marked a significant political shift within the French-speaking constituencies, primarily Wallonia and the Brussels-Capital Region. A notable trend was the success of centre-right parties, particularly the Mouvement Réformateur (MR), which emerged as a dominant force in both regions <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
In Wallonia, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) achieved a significant victory. The results indicated a clear win for right and centre-right parties, with MR securing 26 seats and Les Engagés (formerly CDH) obtaining 17 seats in the Walloon Parliament. This outcome enabled these two parties to quickly form a centre-right coalition government in the region <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>. The new Walloon Government, along with the French Community Government (also led by an MR-Les Engagés coalition), was formed by July 11, 2024, signaling a relatively swift transition driven by the electoral success of MR and Les Engagés and the electoral setback for the Socialist Party (PS) <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>. The MR party president, Georges-Louis Bouchez, interpreted the election results as a public desire for "change and reform" <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation>.

**Brussels-Capital Region:**
The Brussels-Capital Region also witnessed a major political realignment among its French-speaking electorate. For the first time in 15 years, MR became the largest French-speaking party in the region. They secured just under 26% of the vote among French-speaking parties in Brussels, a significant increase from their 2019 score of 16.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085399/the-belgian-elections-biggest-winners-and-losers</citation>. Voters in Brussels have the unique option to vote for either French-speaking or Dutch-speaking party lists, with the French-speaking college being considerably larger, which is reflected in the seat distribution <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/fileadmin/files/BSt/Publikationen/GrauePublikationen/EZ_eupinions_Belgium_the_War_and_the_Vote_02.2024.pdf</citation>. While MR saw overall success, local results varied; for instance, in the Anderlecht municipality of Brussels, the Belgian Worker's Party (PTB/PVDA) emerged as the most popular party, followed by the PS and then MR <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.

**Key French-speaking Parties and Dynamics:**
Several parties play significant roles in the French-speaking political landscape:
*   **Mouvement Réformateur (MR):** (Liberals) Emerged as the main victor in both Wallonia and Brussels, leading the new Walloon government with Les Engagés <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation> <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.
*   **Parti Socialiste (PS):** (Social Democrats) Traditionally a dominant force, the PS experienced an electoral decline but remains a significant player, particularly at the local level in Brussels <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.
*   **Les Engagés:** (Christian Democrats, formerly CDH) Partnered with MR to form the government in Wallonia and the French Community, marking a successful election for the rebranded party <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>.
*   **Parti du Travail de Belgique (PTB/PVDA):** (Radical Left) This party, the only significant national party in Belgium, continued its breakthrough in the French-speaking community, showing strong performance in certain urban areas like Anderlecht <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/monitor/6160-with-the-radical-right-pushing-ahead-in-flanders-and-the-radical-left-in-wallonia-belgium-could-be-divided-after-the-elections</citation>.
*   **Ecolo:** (Greens) Another key party in the French-speaking sphere <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.
*   **DéFI (Démocrate Fédéraliste Indépendant):** A centrist party with a primary focus on Brussels <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-the-key-players-in-defi</citation> <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.

The election outcomes in the French-speaking constituencies indicated a shift towards the centre-right and a desire for political change, leading to new governing coalitions in Wallonia and a reshaped political hierarchy in Brussels.
## Opinion polls

Opinion polls leading up to the 2024 Belgian federal election on June 9th indicated a shifting political landscape, marked by the rise of parties on the far-right and far-left, and a decline in support for several traditional mainstream parties. The overall picture suggested a potentially complex government formation process post-election.

**General Trends**
Polls consistently showed a weakening of traditional party families (liberals, social democrats, and Christian democrats), who collectively garnered less than 50% of the vote in the 2019 elections for the first time since WWII <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. This trend appeared to continue, with more radical alternatives gaining traction. The far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) and the far-left Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) both saw significant increases in support in polling compared to their 2019 results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The Prime Minister's party, Open Vld, faced predictions of historically low results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Polling by Region**

**Flanders:**
In Flanders, the political discourse was heavily influenced by issues of regional identity and immigration.
*   The far-right, Flemish nationalist party Vlaams Belang (VB) consistently polled as one of the largest, if not the largest, party. An Ipsos poll from June 4, 2024, placed VB at 25.8% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Earlier polls in April 2024 also suggested VB would secure at least a quarter of the votes in Flanders <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), another right-leaning Flemish nationalist party, was typically the second-largest party in polls, with the June 4, 2024 Ipsos poll showing them at 21% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The socialist party Vooruit (formerly sp.a) had shown positive trends but saw a dip in support following controversies surrounding its former chairman, polling around 11-15% in 2024. The June 4th poll had Vooruit (VO) at 15.6% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The Christian Democrats (CD&V) were polling around 12.3% in early June 2024 <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PVDA) showed significant gains in Flanders, polling at 10.2% in early June 2024, nearly double its 2019 score <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Open Vld (OVLD), the Flemish liberal party of the Prime Minister, polled at 7%, a significant drop <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Groen (Flemish Greens) were at 6.1% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
Wallonia, the French-speaking southern region, generally leaned more to the left.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) traditionally led in Wallonia. An Ipsos poll from May 20, 2024, showed PS at 22.6%, neck-and-neck with MR <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. An earlier Kantar poll from April 18, 2024, had PS leading more clearly at 25.4% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was the second major force, polling at 22.6% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB, the francophone wing of PVDA) also showed strong support, polling at 14.5% (Ipsos, May 20) to 16% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Les Engagés (LE, formerly cdH, centrist) showed improvement, polling at 18.1% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Ecolo (Francophone Greens) were polling around 8.8% (Ipsos, May 20) to 12.7% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>, indicating a loss of support compared to previous elections <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Brussels:**
The Brussels-Capital Region, officially bilingual but largely French-speaking, presented a distinct political dynamic.
*   Final opinion polls conducted between May 29-31, 2024, indicated that for federal voting intentions, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) held a "healthy lead" at 22.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. This was also reflected in earlier 2024 polls, such as an Ipsos poll from March 18, 2024, which placed MR at 21.8% in Brussels <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB-PVDA) was reported as "tailing" MR in the final May polls at 19.8%, representing a significant increase from their 2019 federal election result <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. The March 18 Ipsos poll showed PVDA at 17.5% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) polled at 15.4% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Some later polls from PolitPro showed varying figures, with one May 20 Ipsos poll indicating Open VLD surprisingly high, which seemed to be an outlier compared to other data and analyses <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Ecolo, the francophone Greens, polled at 14.7% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**National Outlook and Seat Projections**
While specific nationwide seat projections varied between pollsters, the LSE Europp blog in April 2024 noted that Vlaams Belang's projected support in Flanders could translate to approximately 25 seats in the 150-seat federal Chamber of Representatives, potentially making it the largest single party in parliament <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. An April 2023 poll analysis by The Brussels Times suggested that the then-current seven-party "Vivaldi" federal government coalition (PS, MR, Ecolo, Groen, CD&V, Open VLD, Vooruit) was projected to retain a slim majority of 81 seats, down from 87 in 2019 <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections</citation>. However, the declining fortunes of parties like Open Vld suggested that even if a similar coalition were mathematically possible, the internal dynamics would shift significantly <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

The rise of extremist parties (PVDA-PTB and Vlaams Belang), with whom most mainstream parties refused to govern (the "cordon sanitaire" against Vlaams Belang being a key factor), pointed towards another potentially lengthy and complicated government formation process <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
## Background

Belgium's political system is a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy, characterized by a complex structure designed to accommodate its linguistic and cultural diversity <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation> <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>. The country is divided into three regions (Flanders, Wallonia, and Brussels-Capital) and three language communities (Flemish, French, and German-speaking). This division is deeply reflected in its political landscape, with most major political parties having distinct Flemish (Dutch-speaking) and Francophone (French-speaking) counterparts <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. The King serves as the symbolic head of state, while actual executive power resides with the Prime Minister and the federal government <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation>. Historically, Belgium has undergone several state reforms, evolving into its current federal structure, to manage regional and linguistic tensions <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federale_staat</citation>. Coalition governments are the norm, often requiring lengthy negotiations among multiple parties to form a majority in the federal parliament. This system, sometimes referred to as a "particracy," underscores the significant role of political parties in governance <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>.

The period leading up to the 2024 federal election was marked by significant political fragmentation. The previous federal government, a seven-party coalition known as the "Vivaldi" coalition led by Prime Minister Alexander De Croo (Open VLD), took 494 days to form following the May 2019 elections <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. The 2019 election had already highlighted a divided political landscape, with Flanders voting predominantly for right-leaning parties and Wallonia for left-leaning parties <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. Heading into 2024, there was widespread anticipation of a further shift to the right, particularly in Flanders with the rise of the far-right Vlaams Belang party in opinion polls <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation> <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation>. Increased political polarization was also a noted trend <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

The 2024 Belgian federal election was held on June 9, 2024, coinciding with the European Parliament elections and regional elections, making it a "triple election" day for Belgian voters <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008707/making-sense-of-the-belgian-elections</citation>. This election was significant as it was the first federal vote since the COVID-19 pandemic. It was also marked by one of the lowest voter turnouts recorded since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893, despite the legal obligation to vote <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. Key themes dominating the pre-election discourse included socio-economic issues, migration, the potential for further state reform, and the persistent challenge of forming stable governing coalitions in Belgium's complex political environment <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation>.

比利时于2024年6月9日举行了联邦选举，这一天对比利时的政治格局具有重要意义 <citation>https://research.usfq.edu.ec/en/publications/the-2024-belgian-federal-elections-a-race-to-the-right</citation> <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/world/europe/belgium-2024-election.html</citation>。此次联邦选举与欧洲议会选举和地区选举同日进行，构成了比利时政治日历中一个关键的“超级星期日” <citation>http://www.huashang.be/index/news/detail/id/401.html</citation> <citation>https://www.sohu.com/a/784917024_121124414</citation>。比利时以其复杂的多党制、语言社群的分立以及由此产生的联合政府而闻名，使得每一次联邦选举都备受关注 <citation>https://www.oushinet.com/static/content/international/guojinews/2023-12-28/1189974852875879752.html</citation>。

本次选举是在一个充满挑战的背景下进行的，包括后疫情时代的经济复苏、地区间的持续张力以及欧洲整体政治风向的转变。选举结果不仅将决定未来联邦政府的组成，也将对国家未来的政策走向，乃至其在欧盟中的角色产生深远影响。部分观察家认为，2024年的选举可能成为比利时政治史上的一个“转折点” <citation>https://research.usfq.edu.ec/en/publications/the-2024-belgian-federal-elections-a-race-to-the-right</citation> <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>。本报告旨在全面回顾和分析2024年比利时联邦选举的背景、主要参与方、关键议题、选举结果及其对国家政治的潜在影响。
</answer>

任务：写一个报告讨论一下2024_Belgian_federal_election事件,要求详细全面

前面已写的内容：#### French-speaking constituencies

The 2024 Belgian federal election marked a significant political shift within the French-speaking constituencies, primarily Wallonia and the Brussels-Capital Region. A notable trend was the success of centre-right parties, particularly the Mouvement Réformateur (MR), which emerged as a dominant force in both regions <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
In Wallonia, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) achieved a significant victory. The results indicated a clear win for right and centre-right parties, with MR securing 26 seats and Les Engagés (formerly CDH) obtaining 17 seats in the Walloon Parliament. This outcome enabled these two parties to quickly form a centre-right coalition government in the region <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>. The new Walloon Government, along with the French Community Government (also led by an MR-Les Engagés coalition), was formed by July 11, 2024, signaling a relatively swift transition driven by the electoral success of MR and Les Engagés and the electoral setback for the Socialist Party (PS) <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>. The MR party president, Georges-Louis Bouchez, interpreted the election results as a public desire for "change and reform" <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation>.

**Brussels-Capital Region:**
The Brussels-Capital Region also witnessed a major political realignment among its French-speaking electorate. For the first time in 15 years, MR became the largest French-speaking party in the region. They secured just under 26% of the vote among French-speaking parties in Brussels, a significant increase from their 2019 score of 16.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085399/the-belgian-elections-biggest-winners-and-losers</citation>. Voters in Brussels have the unique option to vote for either French-speaking or Dutch-speaking party lists, with the French-speaking college being considerably larger, which is reflected in the seat distribution <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/fileadmin/files/BSt/Publikationen/GrauePublikationen/EZ_eupinions_Belgium_the_War_and_the_Vote_02.2024.pdf</citation>. While MR saw overall success, local results varied; for instance, in the Anderlecht municipality of Brussels, the Belgian Worker's Party (PTB/PVDA) emerged as the most popular party, followed by the PS and then MR <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.

**Key French-speaking Parties and Dynamics:**
Several parties play significant roles in the French-speaking political landscape:
*   **Mouvement Réformateur (MR):** (Liberals) Emerged as the main victor in both Wallonia and Brussels, leading the new Walloon government with Les Engagés <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation> <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.
*   **Parti Socialiste (PS):** (Social Democrats) Traditionally a dominant force, the PS experienced an electoral decline but remains a significant player, particularly at the local level in Brussels <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.
*   **Les Engagés:** (Christian Democrats, formerly CDH) Partnered with MR to form the government in Wallonia and the French Community, marking a successful election for the rebranded party <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>.
*   **Parti du Travail de Belgique (PTB/PVDA):** (Radical Left) This party, the only significant national party in Belgium, continued its breakthrough in the French-speaking community, showing strong performance in certain urban areas like Anderlecht <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/monitor/6160-with-the-radical-right-pushing-ahead-in-flanders-and-the-radical-left-in-wallonia-belgium-could-be-divided-after-the-elections</citation>.
*   **Ecolo:** (Greens) Another key party in the French-speaking sphere <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.
*   **DéFI (Démocrate Fédéraliste Indépendant):** A centrist party with a primary focus on Brussels <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-the-key-players-in-defi</citation> <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.

The election outcomes in the French-speaking constituencies indicated a shift towards the centre-right and a desire for political change, leading to new governing coalitions in Wallonia and a reshaped political hierarchy in Brussels.
## Opinion polls

Opinion polls leading up to the 2024 Belgian federal election on June 9th indicated a shifting political landscape, marked by the rise of parties on the far-right and far-left, and a decline in support for several traditional mainstream parties. The overall picture suggested a potentially complex government formation process post-election.

**General Trends**
Polls consistently showed a weakening of traditional party families (liberals, social democrats, and Christian democrats), who collectively garnered less than 50% of the vote in the 2019 elections for the first time since WWII <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. This trend appeared to continue, with more radical alternatives gaining traction. The far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) and the far-left Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) both saw significant increases in support in polling compared to their 2019 results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The Prime Minister's party, Open Vld, faced predictions of historically low results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Polling by Region**

**Flanders:**
In Flanders, the political discourse was heavily influenced by issues of regional identity and immigration.
*   The far-right, Flemish nationalist party Vlaams Belang (VB) consistently polled as one of the largest, if not the largest, party. An Ipsos poll from June 4, 2024, placed VB at 25.8% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Earlier polls in April 2024 also suggested VB would secure at least a quarter of the votes in Flanders <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), another right-leaning Flemish nationalist party, was typically the second-largest party in polls, with the June 4, 2024 Ipsos poll showing them at 21% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The socialist party Vooruit (formerly sp.a) had shown positive trends but saw a dip in support following controversies surrounding its former chairman, polling around 11-15% in 2024. The June 4th poll had Vooruit (VO) at 15.6% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The Christian Democrats (CD&V) were polling around 12.3% in early June 2024 <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PVDA) showed significant gains in Flanders, polling at 10.2% in early June 2024, nearly double its 2019 score <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Open Vld (OVLD), the Flemish liberal party of the Prime Minister, polled at 7%, a significant drop <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Groen (Flemish Greens) were at 6.1% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
Wallonia, the French-speaking southern region, generally leaned more to the left.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) traditionally led in Wallonia. An Ipsos poll from May 20, 2024, showed PS at 22.6%, neck-and-neck with MR <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. An earlier Kantar poll from April 18, 2024, had PS leading more clearly at 25.4% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was the second major force, polling at 22.6% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB, the francophone wing of PVDA) also showed strong support, polling at 14.5% (Ipsos, May 20) to 16% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Les Engagés (LE, formerly cdH, centrist) showed improvement, polling at 18.1% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Ecolo (Francophone Greens) were polling around 8.8% (Ipsos, May 20) to 12.7% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>, indicating a loss of support compared to previous elections <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Brussels:**
The Brussels-Capital Region, officially bilingual but largely French-speaking, presented a distinct political dynamic.
*   Final opinion polls conducted between May 29-31, 2024, indicated that for federal voting intentions, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) held a "healthy lead" at 22.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. This was also reflected in earlier 2024 polls, such as an Ipsos poll from March 18, 2024, which placed MR at 21.8% in Brussels <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB-PVDA) was reported as "tailing" MR in the final May polls at 19.8%, representing a significant increase from their 2019 federal election result <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. The March 18 Ipsos poll showed PVDA at 17.5% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) polled at 15.4% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Some later polls from PolitPro showed varying figures, with one May 20 Ipsos poll indicating Open VLD surprisingly high, which seemed to be an outlier compared to other data and analyses <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Ecolo, the francophone Greens, polled at 14.7% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**National Outlook and Seat Projections**
While specific nationwide seat projections varied between pollsters, the LSE Europp blog in April 2024 noted that Vlaams Belang's projected support in Flanders could translate to approximately 25 seats in the 150-seat federal Chamber of Representatives, potentially making it the largest single party in parliament <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. An April 2023 poll analysis by The Brussels Times suggested that the then-current seven-party "Vivaldi" federal government coalition (PS, MR, Ecolo, Groen, CD&V, Open VLD, Vooruit) was projected to retain a slim majority of 81 seats, down from 87 in 2019 <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections</citation>. However, the declining fortunes of parties like Open Vld suggested that even if a similar coalition were mathematically possible, the internal dynamics would shift significantly <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

The rise of extremist parties (PVDA-PTB and Vlaams Belang), with whom most mainstream parties refused to govern (the "cordon sanitaire" against Vlaams Belang being a key factor), pointed towards another potentially lengthy and complicated government formation process <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
## Background

Belgium's political system is a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy, characterized by a complex structure designed to accommodate its linguistic and cultural diversity <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation> <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>. The country is divided into three regions (Flanders, Wallonia, and Brussels-Capital) and three language communities (Flemish, French, and German-speaking). This division is deeply reflected in its political landscape, with most major political parties having distinct Flemish (Dutch-speaking) and Francophone (French-speaking) counterparts <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. The King serves as the symbolic head of state, while actual executive power resides with the Prime Minister and the federal government <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation>. Historically, Belgium has undergone several state reforms, evolving into its current federal structure, to manage regional and linguistic tensions <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federale_staat</citation>. Coalition governments are the norm, often requiring lengthy negotiations among multiple parties to form a majority in the federal parliament. This system, sometimes referred to as a "particracy," underscores the significant role of political parties in governance <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>.

The period leading up to the 2024 federal election was marked by significant political fragmentation. The previous federal government, a seven-party coalition known as the "Vivaldi" coalition led by Prime Minister Alexander De Croo (Open VLD), took 494 days to form following the May 2019 elections <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. The 2019 election had already highlighted a divided political landscape, with Flanders voting predominantly for right-leaning parties and Wallonia for left-leaning parties <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. Heading into 2024, there was widespread anticipation of a further shift to the right, particularly in Flanders with the rise of the far-right Vlaams Belang party in opinion polls <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation> <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation>. Increased political polarization was also a noted trend <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

The 2024 Belgian federal election was held on June 9, 2024, coinciding with the European Parliament elections and regional elections, making it a "triple election" day for Belgian voters <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008707/making-sense-of-the-belgian-elections</citation>. This election was significant as it was the first federal vote since the COVID-19 pandemic. It was also marked by one of the lowest voter turnouts recorded since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893, despite the legal obligation to vote <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. Key themes dominating the pre-election discourse included socio-economic issues, migration, the potential for further state reform, and the persistent challenge of forming stable governing coalitions in Belgium's complex political environment <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation>.

Votre météo

La composition des parlements va changer: à combien s'élèvent les indemnités de départ de nos députés?

Partager:

Certains députés n'ont pas été réélus, d'autres partent à la retraite, mais ils quittent le Parlement avec des indemnités parfois conséquentes.

Combien touche un parlementaire sur le départ? Voici quelques exemples: Georges Gilkinet, pour Écolo, a siégé 17 ans à la Chambre et il peut réclamer 359 142€ bruts, donc environ la moitié en net. C'est une somme qu'il peut tout à fait refuser.

Patrick Dewael, ex-président de la Chambre, a siégé 40 ans. Il peut toucher 507 024€

Maggie De Block (Open VLD), qui démissionne, peut toucher 316 000€. Jean-Claude Marcourt, au PS, peut obtenir 265 000€ d'indemnités de départ. C'est exactement t le même chiffre pour François Bellot du côté du MR.

Comment sont calculés ces montants?

Il faut regarder l'ensemble des années qui ont été prestées par un député. On estime qu'un an dans un parlement correspond à deux mois de salaire brut, ce qui correspond au fédéral à 21 000€ . C'est un peu plus au niveau de la région à 23 000.

Si un député a siégé dix ans par exemple, on rajoute un zéro partout: 211 000€, 230 000€. Ce système est légal et il a été créé pour pallier les allocations de chômage puisque les députés n'y ont pas droit.

A noter que ces députés sortants ne vont pas toucher cette somme d'un coup, ils vont recevoir un peu tous les mois pendant cinq ans.

Combien d'argent cela représente-il pour cette législature?

On parle d'environ 40 millions d'euros. Cela profite surtout aux députés les plus anciens puisque ceux qui ont été élus après 2014 sont plafonnés à 24 mois de salaire, peu importe s'ils sont restés le plus longtemps.

Ce montant total global a tendance à baisser, puisque pour la précédente légilasture, cela a coûté environ 50 millions d'euros à la Belgique.

## Retiring Incumbents and Departures

The 2024 Belgian federal election cycle saw a number of established political figures depart from parliament, either through retirement, resignation, or by not being re-elected. These departures often come with significant severance packages, which have been a subject of public discussion.

Several long-serving and prominent politicians were among those leaving their parliamentary roles. For instance:
*   **Patrick Dewael** (Open VLD), a former Speaker of the Chamber of Representatives, concluded a political career spanning 40 years. Upon his departure, he was eligible for a severance payment of €507,024 <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.
*   **Maggie De Block** (Open VLD), a former Minister of Health, also announced her resignation. After her years of service, she was eligible for a severance payment of €316,000 <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.

Beyond these specific figures, the election results led to a broader change in parliamentary composition. Reports indicated that a significant number of deputies would not be returning. For example, one source stated that 207 Belgian deputies lost their seats in the elections <citation>https://www.levif.be/belgique/politique/les-deputes-non-reelus-vont-ils-reellement-couter-36-millions-deuros-a-letat-belge-voici-comment-fonctionnent-les-indemnites-de-sortie/</citation>. In the Brussels regional parliament alone, eighteen outgoing deputies who stood for re-election were not successful <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/bruxelles-dix-huit-deputes-bruxellois-nont-pas-ete-reelus-dimanche/2024-06-10/article/678480</citation>.

The system of severance pay for departing parliamentarians, whether they retire or are not re-elected, has drawn attention. These payments are calculated based on years of service, with one year in parliament corresponding to roughly two months of gross salary. For a federal MP, this could mean around €21,000 per year of service <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>. Some estimates suggested that the total cost of these severance packages for deputies not re-elected could reach tens of millions of euros <citation>https://www.lecho.be/dossiers/elections-en-belgique/les-deputes-non-reelus-recevront-ensemble-20-millions-d-euros-d-indemnites-de-depart/10551367.html</citation> <citation>https://www.dhnet.be/actu/belgique/2024/07/04/jackpot-pour-les-deputes-sortants-certains-toucheront-une-plantureuse-pension-ainsi-quun-demi-million-deuros-WU65XHBJVBE5RDBIN2J24WBQO4/</citation>. This system is designed in part because MPs are not entitled to standard unemployment benefits. However, there is a cap for those elected after 2014, limiting severance to 24 months of salary <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.

The departure of experienced politicians, whether by choice or electoral outcome, marks a transition period and introduces new faces and dynamics into the Belgian political landscape.
</answer>
