任务：写一个报告讨论一下2024_Belgian_federal_election事件,要求详细全面

前面已写的内容：#### French-speaking constituencies

The 2024 Belgian federal election marked a significant political shift within the French-speaking constituencies, primarily Wallonia and the Brussels-Capital Region. A notable trend was the success of centre-right parties, particularly the Mouvement Réformateur (MR), which emerged as a dominant force in both regions <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
In Wallonia, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) achieved a significant victory. The results indicated a clear win for right and centre-right parties, with MR securing 26 seats and Les Engagés (formerly CDH) obtaining 17 seats in the Walloon Parliament. This outcome enabled these two parties to quickly form a centre-right coalition government in the region <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>. The new Walloon Government, along with the French Community Government (also led by an MR-Les Engagés coalition), was formed by July 11, 2024, signaling a relatively swift transition driven by the electoral success of MR and Les Engagés and the electoral setback for the Socialist Party (PS) <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>. The MR party president, Georges-Louis Bouchez, interpreted the election results as a public desire for "change and reform" <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation>.

**Brussels-Capital Region:**
The Brussels-Capital Region also witnessed a major political realignment among its French-speaking electorate. For the first time in 15 years, MR became the largest French-speaking party in the region. They secured just under 26% of the vote among French-speaking parties in Brussels, a significant increase from their 2019 score of 16.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085399/the-belgian-elections-biggest-winners-and-losers</citation>. Voters in Brussels have the unique option to vote for either French-speaking or Dutch-speaking party lists, with the French-speaking college being considerably larger, which is reflected in the seat distribution <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/fileadmin/files/BSt/Publikationen/GrauePublikationen/EZ_eupinions_Belgium_the_War_and_the_Vote_02.2024.pdf</citation>. While MR saw overall success, local results varied; for instance, in the Anderlecht municipality of Brussels, the Belgian Worker's Party (PTB/PVDA) emerged as the most popular party, followed by the PS and then MR <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.

**Key French-speaking Parties and Dynamics:**
Several parties play significant roles in the French-speaking political landscape:
*   **Mouvement Réformateur (MR):** (Liberals) Emerged as the main victor in both Wallonia and Brussels, leading the new Walloon government with Les Engagés <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/observatoire/6212</citation> <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.
*   **Parti Socialiste (PS):** (Social Democrats) Traditionally a dominant force, the PS experienced an electoral decline but remains a significant player, particularly at the local level in Brussels <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.
*   **Les Engagés:** (Christian Democrats, formerly CDH) Partnered with MR to form the government in Wallonia and the French Community, marking a successful election for the rebranded party <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1229472/100-days-after-belgiums-elections-where-are-we-now</citation>.
*   **Parti du Travail de Belgique (PTB/PVDA):** (Radical Left) This party, the only significant national party in Belgium, continued its breakthrough in the French-speaking community, showing strong performance in certain urban areas like Anderlecht <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation> <citation>https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/monitor/6160-with-the-radical-right-pushing-ahead-in-flanders-and-the-radical-left-in-wallonia-belgium-could-be-divided-after-the-elections</citation>.
*   **Ecolo:** (Greens) Another key party in the French-speaking sphere <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.
*   **DéFI (Démocrate Fédéraliste Indépendant):** A centrist party with a primary focus on Brussels <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-the-key-players-in-defi</citation> <citation>https://www.populismstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/DOWNLOAD-REPORT-ON-BELGIUM.pdf</citation>.

The election outcomes in the French-speaking constituencies indicated a shift towards the centre-right and a desire for political change, leading to new governing coalitions in Wallonia and a reshaped political hierarchy in Brussels.
## Opinion polls

Opinion polls leading up to the 2024 Belgian federal election on June 9th indicated a shifting political landscape, marked by the rise of parties on the far-right and far-left, and a decline in support for several traditional mainstream parties. The overall picture suggested a potentially complex government formation process post-election.

**General Trends**
Polls consistently showed a weakening of traditional party families (liberals, social democrats, and Christian democrats), who collectively garnered less than 50% of the vote in the 2019 elections for the first time since WWII <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. This trend appeared to continue, with more radical alternatives gaining traction. The far-right Vlaams Belang (VB) and the far-left Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) both saw significant increases in support in polling compared to their 2019 results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. The Prime Minister's party, Open Vld, faced predictions of historically low results <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Polling by Region**

**Flanders:**
In Flanders, the political discourse was heavily influenced by issues of regional identity and immigration.
*   The far-right, Flemish nationalist party Vlaams Belang (VB) consistently polled as one of the largest, if not the largest, party. An Ipsos poll from June 4, 2024, placed VB at 25.8% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Earlier polls in April 2024 also suggested VB would secure at least a quarter of the votes in Flanders <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), another right-leaning Flemish nationalist party, was typically the second-largest party in polls, with the June 4, 2024 Ipsos poll showing them at 21% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The socialist party Vooruit (formerly sp.a) had shown positive trends but saw a dip in support following controversies surrounding its former chairman, polling around 11-15% in 2024. The June 4th poll had Vooruit (VO) at 15.6% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   The Christian Democrats (CD&V) were polling around 12.3% in early June 2024 <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PVDA) showed significant gains in Flanders, polling at 10.2% in early June 2024, nearly double its 2019 score <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Open Vld (OVLD), the Flemish liberal party of the Prime Minister, polled at 7%, a significant drop <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Groen (Flemish Greens) were at 6.1% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**Wallonia:**
Wallonia, the French-speaking southern region, generally leaned more to the left.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) traditionally led in Wallonia. An Ipsos poll from May 20, 2024, showed PS at 22.6%, neck-and-neck with MR <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. An earlier Kantar poll from April 18, 2024, had PS leading more clearly at 25.4% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) was the second major force, polling at 22.6% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB, the francophone wing of PVDA) also showed strong support, polling at 14.5% (Ipsos, May 20) to 16% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Les Engagés (LE, formerly cdH, centrist) showed improvement, polling at 18.1% in the May 20 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   Ecolo (Francophone Greens) were polling around 8.8% (Ipsos, May 20) to 12.7% (Kantar, April 18) <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>, indicating a loss of support compared to previous elections <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

**Brussels:**
The Brussels-Capital Region, officially bilingual but largely French-speaking, presented a distinct political dynamic.
*   Final opinion polls conducted between May 29-31, 2024, indicated that for federal voting intentions, the Mouvement Réformateur (MR) held a "healthy lead" at 22.9% <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. This was also reflected in earlier 2024 polls, such as an Ipsos poll from March 18, 2024, which placed MR at 21.8% in Brussels <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Workers' Party (PTB-PVDA) was reported as "tailing" MR in the final May polls at 19.8%, representing a significant increase from their 2019 federal election result <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. The March 18 Ipsos poll showed PVDA at 17.5% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.
*   The Socialist Party (PS) polled at 15.4% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>. Some later polls from PolitPro showed varying figures, with one May 20 Ipsos poll indicating Open VLD surprisingly high, which seemed to be an outlier compared to other data and analyses <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation> <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
*   Ecolo, the francophone Greens, polled at 14.7% in the March 18 Ipsos poll <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/2024</citation>.

**National Outlook and Seat Projections**
While specific nationwide seat projections varied between pollsters, the LSE Europp blog in April 2024 noted that Vlaams Belang's projected support in Flanders could translate to approximately 25 seats in the 150-seat federal Chamber of Representatives, potentially making it the largest single party in parliament <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>. An April 2023 poll analysis by The Brussels Times suggested that the then-current seven-party "Vivaldi" federal government coalition (PS, MR, Ecolo, Groen, CD&V, Open VLD, Vooruit) was projected to retain a slim majority of 81 seats, down from 87 in 2019 <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/440289/how-will-belgians-vote-at-the-2024-elections</citation>. However, the declining fortunes of parties like Open Vld suggested that even if a similar coalition were mathematically possible, the internal dynamics would shift significantly <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.

The rise of extremist parties (PVDA-PTB and Vlaams Belang), with whom most mainstream parties refused to govern (the "cordon sanitaire" against Vlaams Belang being a key factor), pointed towards another potentially lengthy and complicated government formation process <citation>https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2024/04/22/belgium-the-2024-federal-elections-deadlock-ahead/</citation>.
## Background

Belgium's political system is a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy, characterized by a complex structure designed to accommodate its linguistic and cultural diversity <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation> <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>. The country is divided into three regions (Flanders, Wallonia, and Brussels-Capital) and three language communities (Flemish, French, and German-speaking). This division is deeply reflected in its political landscape, with most major political parties having distinct Flemish (Dutch-speaking) and Francophone (French-speaking) counterparts <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. The King serves as the symbolic head of state, while actual executive power resides with the Prime Minister and the federal government <citation>https://beentobelgium.com/belgian-government-politics/</citation>. Historically, Belgium has undergone several state reforms, evolving into its current federal structure, to manage regional and linguistic tensions <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federale_staat</citation>. Coalition governments are the norm, often requiring lengthy negotiations among multiple parties to form a majority in the federal parliament. This system, sometimes referred to as a "particracy," underscores the significant role of political parties in governance <citation>https://www.best-country.com/en/europe/belgium/political_structure</citation>.

The period leading up to the 2024 federal election was marked by significant political fragmentation. The previous federal government, a seven-party coalition known as the "Vivaldi" coalition led by Prime Minister Alexander De Croo (Open VLD), took 494 days to form following the May 2019 elections <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. The 2019 election had already highlighted a divided political landscape, with Flanders voting predominantly for right-leaning parties and Wallonia for left-leaning parties <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/330182/belgian-politics-for-dummies-who-is-in-power-where</citation>. Heading into 2024, there was widespread anticipation of a further shift to the right, particularly in Flanders with the rise of the far-right Vlaams Belang party in opinion polls <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation> <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation>. Increased political polarization was also a noted trend <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

The 2024 Belgian federal election was held on June 9, 2024, coinciding with the European Parliament elections and regional elections, making it a "triple election" day for Belgian voters <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008707/making-sense-of-the-belgian-elections</citation>. This election was significant as it was the first federal vote since the COVID-19 pandemic. It was also marked by one of the lowest voter turnouts recorded since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893, despite the legal obligation to vote <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. Key themes dominating the pre-election discourse included socio-economic issues, migration, the potential for further state reform, and the persistent challenge of forming stable governing coalitions in Belgium's complex political environment <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-paul-magnette-belgium-election-politics-nva-socialist-party/</citation>.
## Preface

比利时于2024年6月9日举行了联邦选举，这一天对比利时的政治格局具有重要意义 <citation>https://research.usfq.edu.ec/en/publications/the-2024-belgian-federal-elections-a-race-to-the-right</citation> <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/world/europe/belgium-2024-election.html</citation>。此次联邦选举与欧洲议会选举和地区选举同日进行，构成了比利时政治日历中一个关键的“超级星期日” <citation>http://www.huashang.be/index/news/detail/id/401.html</citation> <citation>https://www.sohu.com/a/784917024_121124414</citation>。比利时以其复杂的多党制、语言社群的分立以及由此产生的联合政府而闻名，使得每一次联邦选举都备受关注 <citation>https://www.oushinet.com/static/content/international/guojinews/2023-12-28/1189974852875879752.html</citation>。

本次选举是在一个充满挑战的背景下进行的，包括后疫情时代的经济复苏、地区间的持续张力以及欧洲整体政治风向的转变。选举结果不仅将决定未来联邦政府的组成，也将对国家未来的政策走向，乃至其在欧盟中的角色产生深远影响。部分观察家认为，2024年的选举可能成为比利时政治史上的一个“转折点” <citation>https://research.usfq.edu.ec/en/publications/the-2024-belgian-federal-elections-a-race-to-the-right</citation> <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>。本报告旨在全面回顾和分析2024年比利时联邦选举的背景、主要参与方、关键议题、选举结果及其对国家政治的潜在影响。
## Retiring Incumbents and Departures

The 2024 Belgian federal election cycle saw a number of established political figures depart from parliament, either through retirement, resignation, or by not being re-elected. These departures often come with significant severance packages, which have been a subject of public discussion.

Several long-serving and prominent politicians were among those leaving their parliamentary roles. For instance:
*   **Patrick Dewael** (Open VLD), a former Speaker of the Chamber of Representatives, concluded a political career spanning 40 years. Upon his departure, he was eligible for a severance payment of €507,024 <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.
*   **Maggie De Block** (Open VLD), a former Minister of Health, also announced her resignation. After her years of service, she was eligible for a severance payment of €316,000 <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.

Beyond these specific figures, the election results led to a broader change in parliamentary composition. Reports indicated that a significant number of deputies would not be returning. For example, one source stated that 207 Belgian deputies lost their seats in the elections <citation>https://www.levif.be/belgique/politique/les-deputes-non-reelus-vont-ils-reellement-couter-36-millions-deuros-a-letat-belge-voici-comment-fonctionnent-les-indemnites-de-sortie/</citation>. In the Brussels regional parliament alone, eighteen outgoing deputies who stood for re-election were not successful <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/bruxelles-dix-huit-deputes-bruxellois-nont-pas-ete-reelus-dimanche/2024-06-10/article/678480</citation>.

The system of severance pay for departing parliamentarians, whether they retire or are not re-elected, has drawn attention. These payments are calculated based on years of service, with one year in parliament corresponding to roughly two months of gross salary. For a federal MP, this could mean around €21,000 per year of service <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>. Some estimates suggested that the total cost of these severance packages for deputies not re-elected could reach tens of millions of euros <citation>https://www.lecho.be/dossiers/elections-en-belgique/les-deputes-non-reelus-recevront-ensemble-20-millions-d-euros-d-indemnites-de-depart/10551367.html</citation> <citation>https://www.dhnet.be/actu/belgique/2024/07/04/jackpot-pour-les-deputes-sortants-certains-toucheront-une-plantureuse-pension-ainsi-quun-demi-million-deuros-WU65XHBJVBE5RDBIN2J24WBQO4/</citation>. This system is designed in part because MPs are not entitled to standard unemployment benefits. However, there is a cap for those elected after 2014, limiting severance to 24 months of salary <citation>https://www.rtl.be/actu/belgique/politique/la-composition-des-parlements-va-changer-combien-selevent-les-indemnites-de/2024-06-12/article/679300</citation>.

The departure of experienced politicians, whether by choice or electoral outcome, marks a transition period and introduces new faces and dynamics into the Belgian political landscape.
### 参议院

2024年比利时联邦选举并未直接选举参议员。根据比利时宪法，参议院的组成方式有所不同。参议院由60名议员组成，其中50名参议员由社群和地区议会从其成员中任命，另外10名参议员由这50名议员根据联邦选举结果进行增选 <citation>https://www.senaat.be/www/?MIval=/index_senate&MENUID=51000&LANG=fr&PAGE=/event/20240422-elections2024/20240610-elections2024_fr.html</citation> <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/22/</citation> <citation>https://www.senate.be/english/SenateCompoEN.html</citation>。

根据2024年6月9日的选举结果，新弗拉芒联盟（N-VA）成为参议院中最大的党派，拥有10个席位（包括任命和增选的参议员）<citation>https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/06/12/flemish-nationalists-largest-party-in-belgian-senate/</citation>。弗拉芒社会主义党Vooruit兑现了其不增选参议员的承诺 <citation>https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/06/12/flemish-nationalists-largest-party-in-belgian-senate/</citation>。比利时工人党（PVDA/PTB）根据其在法语区的选举结果，可能会增选1名参议员 <citation>https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/06/12/flemish-nationalists-largest-party-in-belgian-senate/</citation>。在60个参议院席位中，有59个将根据2024年6月9日的选举结果按比例分配给各政党 <citation>https://www.senate.be/event/20240422-elections2024/2024-renouvellement-Senat.pdf</citation>。

值得注意的是，有组阁协议中提到了废除参议院的计划，但这需要联邦议会两院三分之二多数票的通过才能实现 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BE/BE-LC01/election/BE-LC01-E20240609/</citation>。
## Electoral system

The Belgian federal electoral system is a complex, multi-layered framework designed to ensure proportional representation across its diverse linguistic and regional communities. Key aspects of the system, particularly as they pertained to the 2024 federal election, are outlined below.

**Parliamentary Structure:**
Belgium has a bicameral Federal Parliament, consisting of:
*   **The Chamber of Representatives (Volksvertegenwoordigers / Chambre des Représentants):** This is the lower house and the primary legislative body. It comprises 150 members directly elected by the population for a five-year term <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/22/</citation> <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federal_authorities/federal_parliament</citation>.
*   **The Senate (Senaat / Sénat):** This is the upper house with a more limited legislative role. It has 60 members. Of these, 50 are appointed by the Parliaments of the Communities and the Regions from among their members, and the remaining 10 are co-opted by the Senate itself, also for a five-year term <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/22/</citation> <citation>https://www.belgium.be/en/about_belgium/government/federal_authorities/federal_parliament</citation>. The 2024 federal election directly concerned the election of members to the Chamber of Representatives.

**Voting System:**
*   **Proportional Representation:** Federal elections in Belgium utilize a system of proportional representation. This system aims to allocate seats to political parties in proportion to the number of votes they receive <citation>https://www.detailedpedia.com/wiki-Elections_in_Belgium</citation>. This generally necessitates the formation of coalition governments, as it is rare for a single party to win an outright majority <citation>https://www.detailedpedia.com/wiki-Elections_in_Belgium</citation>.
*   **Flexible-List System:** For the Chamber of Representatives, a flexible-list proportional representation system is employed <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/22/</citation>. Under this system, voters can cast their vote in one of several ways:
    *   Vote for a party list as a whole (a "list vote" or "header vote").
    *   Vote for one or more specific candidates on a single party list (a "preference vote" or "name vote") <citation>https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261379418302877</citation> <citation>https://www.senate.be/english/LegElectionsEN.html</citation>.
    Party votes generally go to the first candidate on the list until they have enough votes to be elected, after which the allocation can be influenced by the number of preference votes received by individual candidates <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/a-guide-to-the-elections-the-voting-process-in-belgium</citation>. The candidates' vote-earning capacity through preference votes is significant in determining who is elected <citation>https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-96460-7_8</citation>.
*   **D'Hondt Method:** The allocation of seats among parties is typically done using the D'Hondt method. This method involves dividing the total number of votes for each party by a series of divisors (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.) to determine quotients. Seats are then awarded to parties with the highest quotients until all seats are filled <citation>https://www.senate.be/english/LegElectionsEN.html</citation>.

**Electoral Constituencies and Threshold:**
*   **Electoral Districts:** For elections to the Chamber of Representatives, the country is divided into electoral districts, which generally correspond to the provinces. However, some specific arrangements exist, notably the division of Flemish Brabant into Brussels-Halle-Vilvoorde (BHV) and Leuven for electoral purposes in the past, though this has seen reforms <citation>https://www.primidi.com/belgian_chamber_of_representatives/members_and_elections</citation> <citation>https://www.electionpassport.com/electoral-systems/belgium/</citation>. For the 2024 election, there were 11 electoral districts <citation>https://www.primidi.com/belgian_chamber_of_representatives/members_and_elections</citation>.
*   **Electoral Threshold:** Generally, there is a 5% electoral threshold in each constituency. Parties must achieve at least 5% of the vote in a constituency to be eligible for seat allocation in that district <citation>https://kids.kiddle.co/Chamber_of_Representatives_(Belgium)</citation> <citation>https://www.primidi.com/belgian_chamber_of_representatives/members_and_elections</citation>. However, there have been exceptions and legal challenges to this threshold in specific constituencies like Brussels-Halle-Vilvoorde, Leuven, and Walloon Brabant in the past <citation>https://www.primidi.com/belgian_chamber_of_representatives/members_and_elections</citation>.

**Voter Eligibility and Compulsory Voting:**
*   **Voting Age:** Belgian citizens aged 18 and over have the right to vote in federal elections <citation>https://www.senate.be/english/LegElectionsEN.html</citation>. For the 2024 European elections, which were held concurrently, Belgium allowed 16- and 17-year-olds to vote, a change adopted in 2023 <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/a-guide-to-the-elections-the-voting-process-in-belgium</citation>.
*   **Compulsory Voting:** Voting in federal elections is mandatory in Belgium <citation>https://www.detailedpedia.com/wiki-Elections_in_Belgium</citation> <citation>https://www.senate.be/english/LegElectionsEN.html</citation>. This has historically resulted in very high turnout rates, although the 2024 elections reportedly saw one of the lowest turnouts since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893 <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

**Election Timing:**
Federal elections, along with regional and European Parliament elections, are generally organized simultaneously every five years <citation>https://be.brussels/en/about-region/elections-et-consultations-publiques/elections/federal-elections</citation>. The 2024 federal elections were held on June 9, 2024, concurrently with European and regional elections <citation>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/391326019_The_2024_Belgian_federal_elections_a_race_to_the_right</citation>.

The Belgian electoral system reflects the country's federal structure and its commitment to representing its linguistic and political diversity, though its complexity often contributes to lengthy government formation processes.

## Aftermath

The aftermath of the 2024 Belgian federal elections on June 9 was characterized by significant political shifts, the resignation of the incumbent prime minister, and a protracted period of complex negotiations to form a new federal government.

Immediately following the election, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo of the Open VLD party announced his resignation after his party suffered considerable losses <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.thebulletin.be/king-philippes-role-formation-belgiums-next-government</citation>. As per constitutional tradition, King Philippe commenced consultations with the leaders of the major political parties to navigate the formation of a new government. Bart De Wever, leader of the Flemish nationalist party N-VA, which emerged as a dominant force particularly in Flanders and secured the most seats overall, was appointed as "informator" and subsequently as "preformator" or "formateur" to spearhead the challenging coalition talks <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1087862/elections-aftermath-live-king-receives-more-visits-talks-start-on-flemish-government-tbtb</citation> <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation>.

The election results signaled a notable turn to the right in Belgian politics. The N-VA and the Francophone liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR) were widely regarded as the primary victors <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation>. While the far-right Vlaams Belang party also saw an increase in its vote share and seat count, it did not succeed in its ambition to become the largest party in Flanders, with N-VA maintaining its leading position in the region <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation> <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-far-right-election-extremist-landslide-elections-in-europe-results-2024/</citation>.

The path to forming a federal government proved to be arduous and lengthy. Bart De Wever pursued the formation of a so-called "Arizona" coalition, envisioned to include his N-VA, the Christian Democratic CD&V, and the socialist Vooruit from the Flemish side, along with the liberal MR and the centrist Les Engagés from the Francophone camp <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation>. These negotiations were fraught with difficulties. Deep divisions emerged, particularly concerning proposed conservative fiscal reforms and tax cuts, which led Vooruit to express concerns about the potential impact on social security and pensions <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation>. Furthermore, the Francophone Socialist Party (PS), having experienced electoral setbacks, announced its decision to enter opposition, further complicating the coalition arithmetic <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation>. The talks experienced several breakdowns; notably, on November 4, 2024, De Wever's efforts faced a major setback when Vooruit withdrew its support for a right-leaning government <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation>. Earlier reports around August 2024 also indicated De Wever had resigned as "formateur," underscoring the persistent challenges <citation>https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/08/23/talks-on-the-formation-of-a-federal-government-what-now/</citation>.

In stark contrast to the federal complexities, the political situation in Wallonia saw a quicker resolution. A regional government was formed by MR and Les Engagés, reflecting the centre-right momentum in the French-speaking part of the country <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1087862/elections-aftermath-live-king-receives-more-visits-talks-start-on-flemish-government-tbtb</citation> <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.

After nearly eight months of intense negotiations and political maneuvering, a new federal government was finally established. On February 3, 2025, the "Arizona" coalition government was sworn in, with Bart De Wever (N-VA) assuming the office of Prime Minister <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>. The new federal cabinet consists of the Prime Minister and 14 ministers, with a linguistic balance of seven Francophone and six Dutch-speaking ministers, alongside the Dutch-speaking premier <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>. The coalition is understood to comprise N-VA, CD&V, and Vooruit from Flanders, and MR and Les Engagés from the Francophone side <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>. Key policy priorities anticipated for the new administration include consolidating federal finances and implementing stricter immigration policies, while N-VA's traditional demands for extensive Flemish self-government appeared to be less prominent in the initial government program <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

Another significant aspect of the 2024 elections was the historically low voter turnout, one of the lowest recorded since the introduction of compulsory voting in Belgium in 1893, marking the election as a noteworthy event in the nation's political landscape <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

Who's in Belgium's new Federal Government?
Monday 3 February 2025
By  Maïthé Chini

The complete Arizona government pictured after the oath ceremony of the new Prime Minister and members of the federal government at the Royal Palace, Monday 03 February 2025, in Brussels. Credit: Belga/Jasper Jacobs
Belgium's new Federal 'Arizona' Government was sworn in on Monday morning before King Philippe, giving the country a fully-fledged administration after nearly eight months.
The casting of the new Federal Government is complete; the 15-member federal cabinet is made up of 14 ministers (seven Francophone, six Dutch-speaking), plus new premier Bart De Wever, a native Dutch speaker.
Contrary to the previous Federal Government, there are no State Secretaries.
The portfolios have been split up between the five parties in the so-called 'Arizona' coalition: the Flemish right-wing N-VA, Christian Democrat CD&V and socialist Vooruit, and the Francophone liberal MR and centrist Les Engagés.

At Last, a Government: New Belgian Coalition Ponders Reforms

N-VA’s leader and Antwerp mayor Bart De Wever
Thierry Roge / POOL / AFP
Consolidated federal finances and tighter immigration policies take priority over Flemish self-government for the ideologically diverse coalition.

Pieter Cleppe
— February 8, 2025

236 days after the June 2024 election, a new federal government coalition has finally been formed in Belgium, the country that still holds the world record of 652 days without a full-fledged government. Forming Belgian federal coalitions has been challenging in the last two decades due to profound ideological differences between political parties from Dutch-speaking Flanders and Francophone parties from Wallonia and the capital region of Brussels, which is officially bilingual.
Traditionally, Flemings tend to vote for rightwing parties, in support of lower taxation and tougher crime and migration policy. In June 2024, however, the right wing gained ground also in Francophone Belgium. In a surprise to pollsters, the left-wing parties —socialists, communists, and greens—suffered a collective defeat. George-Louis Bouchez, the leader of the centre-right Francophone liberals, managed to become the dominant political force and concluded a regional Walloon coalition with the centrist party Les Engages, thereby also committing to joining a federal coalition together.
In Flanders, the centre-right N-VA, led by Antwerp mayor Bart De Wever, equally surprised pollsters by managing to remain the biggest Flemish party ahead of the right-wing populist Vlaams Belang, kept out of government with a cordon sanitaire imposed by all other political parties.
De Wever’s Flemish centre-right nationalist N-VA is now governing in coalition with Francophone liberals and centrists, as well as Flemish Christian democrats and social democrats, The arrangement has been dubbed an “Arizona” coalition, mirroring the colors of the  flag of the American state: yellow for N-VA, orange for Christian democrats, red for socialists, and blue for Francophone liberals and centrists.
In the new federal government program negotiated by Prime Minister De Wever, there is little emphasis on strengthening Flemish self-government, despite the N-VA’s nationalist roots, aiming for Belgium’s gradual dissolution. De Wever once quipped, “From treason to treason, we achieve Flemish statehood,” mocking those in Flemish nationalist circles who view any concession as unacceptable.
During the election campaign, De Wever emphasized that consolidating Belgium’s public finances should be the top priority for the Flemish region, which accounts for about 80% of Belgian exports with only 60% of the population. The outgoing federal government, dominated by socialists and greens, left a massive budget hole, along with other irresponsible policies, such as the closure of perfectly functional nuclear power plants, despite the 2022 energy crisis.
The new government programme includes a number of measures that should help consolidate the budget. All in all, the reforms are quite modest, given how a majority was only possible by including the Flemish socialist party and the left-leaning Flemish Christian Democrats. A key measure is that citizens will need to work slightly longer before being able to enjoy a full state pension. Belgian taxes on salaries—the highest in the world—will be slightly reduced. The centre-right parties had to concede the introduction of a general capital gains tax—pretty much the only tax that did not yet exist in the world’s most heavily taxed country. Furthermore, it will no longer be possible to enjoy unemployment benefits indefinitely. Belgium was one of the only countries in the world offering this arrangement.
The hope is that these measures will drastically reduce the high number of working-age people who are currently not employed. This is a challenge especially in the Francophone part of the country, something De Wever has cited to argue that at least some of his policies align with his regionalist beliefs. He is not wrong. Without the Francophone socialist party—which has been blocking these sensible reforms for years—it has now become possible to introduce these measures.
When it comes to immigration policy, Belgium is about to tighten things up by no longer providing private housing to asylum seekers, but instead collective reception centers. Asylum seekers who have already been rejected by another EU country won’t be able to enjoy housing if there is a shortage. Family reunification will be limited by increasing the income threshold and requiring a language and citizenship test. The new government will also explore sending illegal immigrants who commit crimes to serve their sentences in prisons abroad. Notably, it will also unify the six police zones in Brussels into a single one, against the resistance of the 19 Brussels mayors, who are wary of losing power.
Observers are skeptical whether these policies will suffice to plug Belgium’s budget deficit, which, at almost 5%, is among the biggest in the Western world. In any case, PM De Wever still wants Belgium to become a “confederation.” Before the 2024 election, he even stated that if this worked well, to him, Flemish independence was no longer necessary. The government agreement includes little in this area, only committing to ongoing exploration of institutional reforms. A two-thirds majority in the Belgian Lower House is required to pass such reforms, but financial pressure could potentially help achieve these numbers over time.
The Brussels region, which is struggling to form a new government, has a whopping 40 percent budget deficit. State-owned bank Belfius has warned the Walloon region it may cease refinancing, having already refused to finance several Walloon cities. The Flemish region, meanwhile, seems to be swimming in cash, as it is able to spend a massive €18 billion on subsidies.
As a consequence, consolidating the fiscal situation of Belgium’s federal and regional policy levels most likely requires large-scale institutional reform.
The obvious solution would be to transfer competences like health care and pensions from the federal level to the regional entities—this is more or less the case in Spain and Germany—without fully transferring the budgets for this. Something along these lines already happened with the sixth big institutional reform in Belgium, passed fifteen years ago, but only for a select number of competences.
If repeated on a large scale, the Flemish government would be forced to cut subsidies in order to finance its newly acquired competences. The already virtually bankrupt Francophone regional entities would then get new resources to pay for their new competences, dependent on implementing an—IMF or the euro zone Troika style—adjustment programme. It is not hard to see why Belgium’s political class is keen to postpone something like this for as long as possible, but at some point, the pressure may become too big.
Ideally, at the heart of future Belgian institutional reform would be to grant every policy level the taxation power required to finance whatever is within its competences. This would send the right incentives throughout the system, as politicians would know that every spending decision will also carry a requirement to impose taxes. The great model for this is Switzerland. In no other country, decentralised entities enjoy more taxing power than over there. In countries where decentralisation is only a sham, such as the UK, decentralised policy levels are mainly allowed to spend money they get from the central authority. Typically, the central authority resists giving up taxation power.

Elections 2024: Belgium’s federal government crisis deepens as possible coalition nears collapse

4 November 2024

After months of fruitless negotiations, Bart De Wever is expected to tender his resignation as formateur on Monday. It will push Belgium into a precarious situation with few viable alternatives remaining.

After the 9 June elections, many Belgians kept their hopes up for a quick federal government formation. With the right-wing N-VA, led by De Wever, emerging as the winner in Flanders and the liberal MR dethroning the socialists in Wallonia, a coalition was, according to many observers, within reach. However, the centre-right alliance De Wever tried to form - involving his own party, Les Engagés, MR, the Christian Democratic CD&V and the socialist Vooruit party - has been facing insurmountable friction over the past few weeks.

Socialist resistance

Conner Rousseau, chairman of Vooruit, has become the key obstacle, openly rejecting the proposed framework. Rousseau has argued that, as the only left-leaning party, Vooruit cannot agree to a coalition that prioritises conservative fiscal reforms and tax cuts, fearing these measures would compromise social security and pensions.

De Wever’s efforts to mediate fell short, even after multiple revisions to the coalition’s “super memo,” a comprehensive draft designed to appeal across party lines. Rousseau remained unmoved, to the frustration of other party leaders such as Maxime Prévot of Les Engagés.

Options

As De Wever prepares to inform the king on Monday, speculation mounts over what could follow. Alternatives to the intended coalition are bleak. The Flemish liberals (Open VLD) could replace Vooruit, which might ease ideological tensions but would leave the coalition with a razor-thin and possibly unworkable majority. Other options would require Wallonia’s socialists to get aboard, but PS chairman Paul Magnette is adamant about staying out of government after his party’s losses in the last elections.

Each scenario thus appears increasingly unviable, leaving the king with limited choices. If the current negotiating parties cannot overcome their differences, it seems unlikely that the current deadlock will be resolved. A crisis like in 2010-11, when Belgium needed a record 541 days to form a federal government, might be looming.

Belgian federal government talks collapse, again

Share

After 148 days of negotiations, talks to form a government in Belgium have failed.
On November 4, Bart De Wever, head of the centre-right N-VA party and lead negotiator, threw in the towel after the Flemish Socialists announced they would not support forming a right-wing government.
De Wever went to see the King of Belgium, the formal Head of State, to announce his resignation from the post of coalition negotiator. King Philip said he would postpone accepting this resignation until November 12, giving De Wever an extra week to find a solution, though few believe the situation will change.


 


In national elections on June 9, the electorate chose clear winners and losers.
In Wallonia, the Socialist Party and the Green Party took a historical beating, while the Liberals and Christian Democrats, who both shifted to the Right, did well, creating opportunities for change.
In Flanders, the results were more mixed. On one hand, the hard-right Vlaams Belang Party did well, although it underperformed compared to poll predictions. The so-called “cordon sanitaire” prevents other parties from working with Vlaams Belang.
The centre-right N-VA lost seats but exceeded expectations, retaining its position as the country’s largest party. The Socialist Party and Communist Party also did well.
On the other hand, the Liberal Party collapsed, together with the Green Party.
Historically, Flanders and Wallonia were often pitted against each other within Belgium, with a right-leaning Flemish electorate frustrated by a left-leaning Walloon bloc. Today, however, Wallonia is no longer the main obstacle; instead, it is the Socialists in Flanders who hold an outsized role in shaping outcomes. Given the gains made by Flemish Socialists, their votes would be needed to form any comfortable federal majority.
These Socialists, however, have no appetite to create a right-leaning government. Opposition from Conner Rousseau, the party’s Flemish leader, was said to be one of the reasons the talks broke down on November 4.
Initially, Rousseau was open to supporting a centre-right government based on the promise of “moderate” policies and certain concessions.
When a draft of the potential coalition agreement was leaked to the public, though, the powerful Socialist Union fiercely opposed it, with its president Miranda Ulens declaring that it would “set us back 80 years.”
Since then, the Flemish Socialists have shown signs of reluctance to join the so-called ‘Arizona’ coalition of centre-right Flemish nationalists, Christian Democrats from both sides and Walloon Liberals.
Adding to this was an episode in the city of Ghent, where the local Socialists turned on the N-VA, saying the party was too right-wing. That weakened the position of Rousseau, suggesting he could not convince his own troops to follow him and illustrating opposition to the Right at the base level.
On November 4, all parties that were part of the national negotiations turned on Rousseau.
He was called a “deserter” and accused of leaving his country behind in its hour of need; Belgium’s debt and high deficits have become a cause for alarm. The country is on the watchlist of all international financial institutions, while the European Commission has started an Excessive Deficit Procedure.
Party presidents who were negotiating with the Socialist leader complained he did not seem to want to do his part and accused him of playing games and wasting time.
When defending himself, Rousseau said his party was willing to fix the budget but added that efforts to do so must be fairly distributed, effectively meaning the rich should pay more.
Relationships between all the negotiating partners have not been smooth.
A compelling need to make deep cuts to get the budget back on track and find more than €2 billion in the short term, combined with the need for extra spending on defence, have added to a growing sense of frustration among Belgian politicians. Many now fear the country is set for a long period under a caretaker government.
One possible solution could have been the entry into the coalition of the Flemish Liberal Party of outgoing Belgian PM Alexander De Croo – but an election beating has left his party on the ropes. Its entry would in any case have left the federal government with a worryingly small majority.
Belgium has seen record-long government formation negotiations. After the elections in 2010, 541 days were needed to form a working administration.
De Croo’s 2020 government needed 652 days to take shape and only did so because there was a crisis due to Covid, forcing the disparate parties to work together.
In the past 14 years, for around one-fourth of the time, Belgium has not had a fully functioning national government, meaning much-needed reforms have been left on the back-burner.

What's the latest on Belgium's Federal Government formation?
Wednesday 10 July 2024
By  Maïthé Chini

Bart De Wever pictured during an extra plenary session of the Chamber at the Federal Parliament in Brussels, on Thursday 04 July 2024. Credit: Belga/Nicolas Maeterlinck
As the Flemish socialist party Vooruit agreed to give the talks to form the Federal Government "a fair chance" following a meeting on Tuesday, preformator and leader of the rightwing N-VA Bart De Wever will likely be appointed as official "formator" on Wednesday.
Since the elections of 9 June, De Wever has been trying (first as an "informator" and for the last two weeks as "preformator") to form a Federal Government. On the Flemish side this would involve his N-VA party, Vooruit and centrist CD&V on the Francophone side it would include the liberal MR and centrist Les Engagés parties.
This coalition would reflect the regional government formations: N-VA, CD&V and Vooruit in Flanders; MR and Les Engagés in Wallonia. Both regions are currently carrying out intense negotiations.
Compromise and red lines
While very little information about the federal formation talks with De Wever is leaking to the press, a source told Belga News Agency that discussions are constructive, with De Wever making efforts to attend to the demands and red lines of all involved parties.
However, in recent weeks Vooruit has put the brakes on negotiations. As the only party of the left (without the support of its French-speaking sister party PS), Vooruit finds itself alone among centre-right partners. It would face PS, the Greens and the radical left PTB-PVDA in opposition.
Vooruit has insisted on guarantees that no cuts will be made to the healthcare sector and protections for the purchasing power of working people. It is also pushing to ensure that those with greater financial security contribute more to State finances.
While the party leaders of the envisaged coalition have been meeting for informal information sessions over the past week, Tuesday's meeting aimed to convince the Flemish socialists to give the go-ahead, allowing full-fledged government negotiations to proceed.
Following the meeting with De Wever, Vooruit's Conner Rousseau said that "an objective shift" had happened, which is why the party is now ready to give the negotiations a fair chance. "The party has given us the confidence for a best-efforts commitment," he explained. In other words, if things go the wrong way during the negotiations, Vooruit can still leave the table.
N-VA leader Bart De Wever talks to the press during the post-election meeting. Credit: Belga / Nicolas Maeterlinck
Jan Jambon (one of N-VA negotiators) believes there is a chance that De Wever can officially start forming the government from Wednesday. "I think it is doable," Jambon told reporters before the talks on Tuesday afternoon. "It is a crucial moment now. I hope that every party is willing to negotiate because the country needs a government."
Other party leaders were also positive after the meeting. MR leader Georges-Louis Bouchez said there is more agreement between the parties currently negotiating than there were for the previous "Vivaldi" Federal Government. "In terms of security, migration and even the labour market, they can do more with us than with the PS and the Greens. There are enough elements to move forward."
Party leader of Les Engagés Maxime Prévot said that his party "fully agrees" to start negotiations now: "We are ready to form a new government as quickly as possible."
Formator?
CD&V leader Sammy Mahdi said that Tuesday's meeting was a "good conversation", adding that "there was a constructive attitude in the room". He said that all parties were eager not to go around in circles.
CD&V is satisfied with De Wever's concessions in the negotiations: "Our priorities – fiscal reform and healthcare – have been sufficiently taken into account. We have an opportunity to do great things."
Preformator De Wever is expected at the Royal Palace at 10:00 on Wednesday. Now Vooruit indicated that negotiations can start, he could possibly leave his meeting with the King as formator – meaning he can officially start leading the negotiations for the coalition agreement. Should that be the case, it becomes increasingly likely that De Wever will also become Prime Minister.

## Aftermath

The aftermath of the 2024 Belgian federal elections on June 9 was characterized by immediate high-level political shifts, a protracted and challenging government formation process, and the eventual establishment of a new federal coalition with a distinct rightward lean.

**Immediate Political Fallout and Initial Negotiations**
Following a significant defeat for his Open VLD party, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo tendered his resignation to King Philippe on June 10, 2024 <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.thebulletin.be/king-philippes-role-formation-belgiums-next-government</citation>. The King then commenced consultations with leaders of the major parties, including Bart De Wever of the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), Tom Van Grieken of the far-right Vlaams Belang, and Georges-Louis Bouchez of the Francophone liberal Reformist Movement (MR) <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation>. The election results signaled a "race to the right" <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. The N-VA maintained its position as the largest party in Flanders, while MR emerged as a dominant force in Wallonia. Vlaams Belang saw an increase in its vote share but failed to overtake N-VA and remained isolated by the "cordon sanitaire" – an agreement among other parties not to govern with them <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. Notably, the election recorded one of the lowest voter turnouts since the introduction of compulsory voting in 1893 <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

**A Lengthy and Arduous Path to Government Formation**
Bart De Wever (N-VA) was appointed by the King, first as "informateur" and subsequently as "formateur," to lead the complex task of building a federal government coalition <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation>. The process proved to be exceptionally challenging, extending for 236 days, or nearly eight months <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation> <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>. Negotiations for the proposed "Arizona" coalition – comprising N-VA, the Christian Democratic CD&V, and the socialist Vooruit from Flanders, with MR and the centrist Les Engagés from Wallonia – faced considerable friction. A key sticking point was the reluctance of Vooruit, as the sole left-leaning party in the potential coalition, to agree to conservative fiscal reforms and tax cuts, fearing negative impacts on social security and pensions <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation>.
Talks reached a critical impasse around November 4, 2024, when Vooruit, under leader Conner Rousseau, effectively rejected the proposed framework for a right-leaning government. This led De Wever to offer his resignation as formateur to the King, who initially postponed its acceptance, allowing a final window for a breakthrough <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation> <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation>. The Francophone Socialist Party (PS), having suffered significant losses, had already declared its intention to remain in opposition <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation>.

**The "Arizona" Coalition Takes Office**
Eventually, an agreement was reached, and the new "Arizona" federal government was sworn in on February 3, 2025 <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. Bart De Wever (N-VA) assumed the role of Prime Minister, leading a cabinet of 14 ministers (seven Francophone and six Dutch-speaking) in addition to himself, with no state secretaries appointed <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>.
The new government's program prioritizes consolidating Belgium’s public finances, which faced a deficit of nearly 5% <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. Other key policy areas include implementing tighter immigration measures, such as shifting from private housing to collective reception centers for asylum seekers and limiting family reunification. **Broader Implications and Regional Dynamics**

## Aftermath

The aftermath of the 9 June 2024 Belgian federal elections was characterized by a significant shift to the right, the resignation of the incumbent Prime Minister, and a protracted and complex period of government formation, culminating in a new federal administration nearly eight months later.

**Immediate Post-Election Landscape and Initial Negotiations**

Following a poor showing for his Open VLD party, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo tendered his resignation to King Philippe on the Monday after the elections, a standard procedural step <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://www.thebulletin.be/king-philippes-role-formation-belgiums-next-government</citation>. The election results confirmed a move to the right, with the Flemish right-wing New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) remaining the largest party in Flanders and the Francophone liberal Reformist Movement (MR) emerging as a major victor in Wallonia <citation>https://www.politico.eu/article/bart-de-wever-alexander-de-croo-georges-louis-bouchez-tom-van-grieken-belgium-election/</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. The far-right Vlaams Belang also gained seats but did not overtake N-VA, with the "cordon sanitaire" preventing its inclusion in government talks <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected/</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

King Philippe began consultations with party leaders, appointing N-VA leader Bart De Wever first as "informator" and subsequently as "preformator" to explore potential coalition options <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation>. The focus quickly turned to forming a so-called "Arizona" coalition, named for the colors of the US state's flag, which would involve N-VA, the Christian Democratic CD&V, and the socialist Vooruit party from the Flemish side, and MR and the centrist Les Engagés from the Francophone side <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. This potential coalition reflected the regional governments being formed in Flanders (N-VA, CD&V, Vooruit) and Wallonia (MR, Les Engagés) <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

However, negotiations proved difficult from the outset. Vooruit, as the only left-leaning party in the proposed federal coalition, expressed significant reservations about joining a government dominated by centre-right partners, particularly concerning conservative fiscal reforms, tax cuts, and their potential impact on social security and pensions <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation> <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation>. In July 2024, Vooruit, led by Conner Rousseau, agreed to give the talks a "fair chance" after De Wever reportedly made efforts to address their concerns <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1132172/whats-the-latest-on-belgiums-federal-government-formation</citation>.

**Collapse of Talks and Renewed Efforts**

Despite initial cautious optimism, the deep-seated ideological differences, particularly regarding socio-economic policies, led to a crisis in the negotiations. On November 4, 2024, after 148 days of talks, Bart De Wever announced the collapse of the negotiations and tendered his resignation as "formateur" to the King <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation> <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation>. The primary reason cited was Vooruit's refusal to support a right-leaning government program that they felt would compromise social protections <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/elections-2024-belgiums-federal-government-crisis-deepens-as-possible-coalition-nears-collapse</citation> <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation>. King Philippe postponed accepting De Wever's resignation, urging further efforts to find a solution amidst fears of a prolonged period of political instability, potentially echoing the 541-day crisis of 2010-2011 <citation>https://brusselssignal.eu/2024/11/belgian-federal-government-talks-collapse-again/</citation>.

The specific details of how the deadlock was overcome in the subsequent months are not extensively publicized, but negotiations eventually resumed. After 236 days since the election, a breakthrough was achieved <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

**Formation of the "Arizona" Government**

On Monday, February 3, 2025, Belgium's new Federal "Arizona" Government was sworn in before King Philippe, with N-VA's Bart De Wever as the new Prime Minister <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>. The coalition comprises the Flemish right-wing N-VA, Christian Democrat CD&V, and socialist Vooruit, alongside the Francophone liberal MR and centrist Les Engagés <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation> <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

The 15-member federal cabinet includes 14 ministers (seven Francophone, six Dutch-speaking) plus the Prime Minister. Key appointments include:
*   **Jan Jambon (N-VA):** Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance and Combating Fiscal Fraud, Pensions, National Lottery and Cultural Institutions.
*   **David Clarinval (MR):** Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Works, Economy and Agriculture.
*   **Maxime Prévot (Les Engagés):** Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, European Affairs and Development Cooperation.
*   **Frank Vandenbroucke (Vooruit):** Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Public Health and Social Affairs.
*   **Vincent Van Peteghem (CD&V):** Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Budget and Administrative Simplification <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1424985/whos-in-belgiums-new-federal-government</citation>.

**Policy Agenda of the New Government**

The new government's program prioritizes consolidating Belgium's strained public finances and implementing tighter immigration policies <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. Given the ideologically diverse nature of the coalition, the reforms are described as somewhat modest. Key measures include requiring citizens to work slightly longer for a full state pension, a slight reduction in Belgium's high taxes on salaries, the introduction of a capital gains tax, and ending the indefinite provision of unemployment benefits <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

On immigration, the government plans to move away from private housing for asylum seekers towards collective reception centers, limit family reunification through increased income thresholds and language/citizenship tests, and explore sending illegal immigrants who commit crimes to serve sentences abroad. It also intends to unify the six police zones in Brussels into a single entity <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

Despite N-VA's nationalist roots and long-term aim for Belgium's gradual dissolution into a confederation, the immediate government program places less emphasis on strengthening Flemish self-government. However, the agreement includes a commitment to ongoing exploration of institutional reforms, though such changes would require a challenging two-thirds majority in parliament <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>. The significant budget deficits at regional levels, particularly in Brussels and Wallonia, are seen as potential future drivers for more substantial institutional reform <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.

The elections also recorded one of the lowest turnouts since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893, marking a notable feature of this political cycle <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>. Observers remain skeptical about whether the announced policies will be sufficient to address Belgium's significant budget deficit and complex institutional challenges <citation>https://europeanconservative.com/articles/analysis/at-last-a-government-new-belgian-coalition-ponders-reforms/</citation>.
</answer>
